protocol_name: BIOL 354W - Research Methods in Advance Microbiology
protocol_name_html: BIOL 354W - Research Methods in Advance Microbiology
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"6t9u9","text":"This protocol series will guide students through the experience of analyzing metagenomic data. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.data:
{"blocks":[{"key":"d4427","text":"The first step in analyzing the sequencing data set is to asses the quality of the sequence, and then to edit the dataset in order to retain only the highest quality sequences for the following analysis. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8b20d","text":" {"blocks":[{"key":"3klmb","text":"To assemble our metagenomes we will try two differnet assemblies and compare them.  We will try IDBA_UD and Megahit assemblies. These is going to be one of the most time intensive process that we will do in the class.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f9d5g","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aqocm","text":"Megahit github - https://github.com/voutcn/megahit/","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"31qsm","text":"Megahit article - https://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article/31/10/1674/177884","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eujs4","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fqh64","text":" /opt/BioInfo_tools/megahit/megahit -1 file_R1.fq.gz -2 file_R2.fq.gz -o megahit_out -t 5 file_R1.fq.gz = your trimmed forward or R1 reads file_R2.fq.gz = your trimmed reversed or R2 reads megahit_out = output folder - you can call it what ever you want and you don't need to make it before your run the software If you run the command unsuccessfully the first time, it will still make a (mostly)blank "megahit_out" folder. Before running the command again, make sure to delete the (mostly)empty "megahit_out" folder ( rm -r megahit_out or rmdir megahit_out) ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":559,"key":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"6i2tj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ak6ua","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"52gph","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":4997,"guid":"751EAD71F38D4F13AD027F74E896BAB5","name":"/storage/BioInfo_tools/megahit/megahit -1 file_R1.fq.gz -2 file_R2.fq.gz -o megahit_out -t 5","description":"file_R1.fq.gz = your trimmed forward or R1 reads
file_R2.fq.gz = your trimmed reversed or R2 reads
megahit_out = output folder - you can call it what ever you want and you don't need to make it before your run the software","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"file_R1.fq.gz = your trimmed forward or R1 reads
file_R2.fq.gz = your trimmed reversed or R2 reads
megahit_out = output folder - you can call it what ever you want and you don't need to make it before your run the software","can_edit":true}}],"guid":"A340D117D1A94E6FB3EE6B45B923B20E","id":675073,"previous_id":675077,"previous_guid":"1EBA3A854D7F45C0BFF3BD435DE00843","section":"Metagenomic assembly "}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e2e3r","text":"We can investigate assembly statistics to compare which assembly is best between the two assemblies utilized. For this we can use a software called Quast.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"defmf","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3icg3","text":"Metrics based only on contigs:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eqlgc","text":"Number of large contigs (i.e., longer than 500 bp) and total length of them.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"be7he","text":"Length of the largest contig.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"88rap","text":"N50 (length of a contig, such that all the contigs of at least the same length together cover at least 50% of the assembly).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7repe","text":"Number of predicted genes, discovered either by GeneMark.hmm (for prokaryotes), GeneMark-ES or GlimmerHMM (for eukaryotes), or MetaGeneMark (for metagenomes).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"97g8i","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":0}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":5001,"guid":"2440BEF986CB462497C2C907FE0FB98D","name":"\/storage\/BioInfo_tools\/quast\/metaquast.py contig.fa --gene-finding -t  5","description":"QUAST evaluates genome assemblies by computing various metrics.\n","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"QUAST evaluates genome assemblies by computing various metrics.\n","can_edit":true}}],"guid":"CA150A51C4284CC9A6D1D9A18B85B566","id":675074,"previous_id":675073,"previous_guid":"A340D117D1A94E6FB3EE6B45B923B20E","section":"Assessing the quality of the assemblies"}
steps.section: Assessing the quality of the assemblies

steps.data:
{"blocks":[{"key":"9dllg","text":"MaxBin is a software for binning assembled metagenomic sequences based on an Expectation-Maximization algorithm.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4ctsi","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2lrv7","text":"Users provide the assembled metagenomic sequences and the reads coverage information or sequencing reads. MaxBin will report genome-related statistics, including estimated completeness, GC content and genome size in the binning summary page.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b9q","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1a9ut","text":"MaxBin article - https://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article/32/4/605/1744462","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"64i3l","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9k82i","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4vkgl","text":" perl /opt/BioInfo_tools/MaxBin-2.2.4/run_MaxBin.pl -contig "assembled_contigs.fa" -reads "interleaved reads fasta" -out "out directory" -thread 5 MaxBin requires the assembled contains file and also the file that contains the sequence reads assembled_contigs.fa = your contigs file (remember to add the full path if you are in a different directory) concatenated reads fasta = the path to your reads, these reads most all be in one file and concatenate ( or paired R1 followed by R2 reads). This you can get from your IDBA fq2fa run out directory = a directory that you create to save your bins ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":596,"key":0}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":5002,"guid":"8230C1E50D2A429DB30D237E1D0AADE2","name":"perl /storage/BioInfo_tools/MaxBin-2.2.4/run_MaxBin.pl -contig "assembled_contigs.fa" -reads "reads file" -reads2 "readsfile" -out "out directory" -thread 5","description":"MaxBin requires the assembled contains file and also the file that contains the sequence reads
assembled_contigs.fa = your contigs file (remember to add the full path if you are in a different directory)
reads = the path to your reads ( or paired R1 followed by R2 reads). 
out directory = a directory that you create to save your bins","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"MaxBin requires the assembled contains file and also the file that contains the sequence reads
assembled_contigs.fa = your contigs file (remember to add the full path if you are in a different directory)
reads = the path to your reads ( or paired R1 followed by R2 reads). 
out directory = a directory that you create to save your bins","can_edit":true}}],"guid":"32939408D30F4D38B531AE30945222F4","id":675075,"previous_id":675074,"previous_guid":"CA150A51C4284CC9A6D1D9A18B85B566","section":"Binning assembled metagenomes with MaxBin"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2obp7","text":"Checkm article - http://genome.cshlp.org/content/25/7/1043","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"92uv","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e20d6","text":"Also check out the websit for information on CheckM - CheckM website","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":54,"length":14,"key":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"9slht","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"347v8","text":"Befor running Checkm the software pplacer must be included in the PATH by addind ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4d9ov","text":"export PATH="/storage/anaconda3/bin:$PATH"" to the .bashrc file in your home directory under the ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fdnio","text":"# User specific aliases and functions section. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e7pdr","text":" nano .bashrc ##copy and paste User specific aliases and functions export PATH="/opt/anaconda3/bin:$PATH" ## Save file changes by "control + O" and then "control + X", then close the window and log in again to the server Add export PATH="/opt/anaconda3/bin:$PATH" underneath the section # User specific aliases and functions by using nano to modify the file .bashrc in you home directory ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":388,"key":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"29p2","text":" /usr/bin/checkm lineage_wf -x fasta ./bins_folder ./checkm_out_folder -t 5 CheckM will assess the quality of each of your bins. All bins most be in the same directory/folder. All bins most have a .fasta ending bins_folder = the path to the folder where your bins are located ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":276,"key":2}],"data":[]},{"key":"239ce","text":" /usr/bin/checkm qa lineage.ms . -o 2 This command will help you generate an expanded information table about each of your bins. Run this command from within the directory where your checkm data is located copy the table that this command generated onto an excel sheet and analyze to then run VizBin ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":300,"key":3}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"url":"https://github.com/Ecogenomics/CheckM/wiki"}},{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":5003,"guid":"4327C16395824BD99430AE9A715A8B49","name":"nano .bashrc

export PATH="/storage/anaconda3/bin:$PATH" 

## Save file changes by "control + O" and then "control + X", then close the window and log in again to the server","description":"","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"","can_edit":true}},{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":5004,"guid":"3B968BF6A5EA437493648A9946D23333","name":"/usr/bin/checkm lineage_wf -x fasta ./bins_folder ./checkm_out_folder -t 5","description":"CheckM will assess the quality of each of your bins. All bins most be in the same directory/folder. All bins most have a .fasta ending

Run this command from within the directory where your checkm data is located
copy the table that this command generated onto an excel sheet and analyze to then run VizBin","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"This command will help you generate an expanded information table about each of your bins. copy the table that this command generated onto an excel sheet and analyze to then run VizBin","can_edit":true}}],"guid":"307A5C7A8AFB42879E2591A87D8BA9DB","id":675076,"previous_id":675075,"previous_guid":"32939408D30F4D38B531AE30945222F4","section":"Assessing the quality of your bins via CheckM"}

steps.data: {"blocks":[{"key":"ad00e","text":"Trimmomatic: A flexible read trimming tool for Illumina NGS data (Website\u00a0)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":66,"length":7,"key":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"8eagc","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fthl1","text":"Description","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b1pl1","text":"Trimmomatic performs a variety of useful trimming tasks for illumina paired-end and single ended data.The selection of trimming steps and their associated parameters are supplied on the command line.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c6s6q","text":"The current trimming steps are:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"52evq","text":"ILLUMINACLIP: Cut adapter and other illumina-specific sequences from the read.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f58i2","text":"SLIDINGWINDOW: Perform a sliding window trimming, cutting once the average quality within the window falls below a threshold.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"abq1q","text":"LEADING: Cut bases off the start of a read, if below a threshold quality","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9bnga","text":"TRAILING: Cut bases off the end of a read, if below a threshold quality","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9pvk1","text":"CROP: Cut the read to a specified length","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5f45j","text":"HEADCROP: Cut the specified number of bases from the start of the read","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1vd20","text":"MINLEN: Drop the read if it is below a specified length","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7bdpn","text":"TOPHRED33: Convert quality scores to Phred-33","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9uk98","text":"TOPHRED64: Convert quality scores to Phred-64","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cikl5","text":" java -jar \/opt\/BioInfo_tools\/Trimmomatic-0.36\/trimmomatic-0.36.jar PE -threads 5 -phred33 input_forward.fq.gz input_reverse.fq.gz output_forward_paired.fq.gz output_forward_unpaired.fq.gz output_reverse_paired.fq.gz output_reverse_unpaired.fq.gz ILLUMINACLIP:\/opt\/BioInfo_tools\/Trimmomatic-0.36\/adapters\/TruSeq3-PE.fa:2:30:10 LEADING:15 TRAILING:15 SLIDINGWINDOW:4:15 MINLEN:36 input_forward.fq.gz = \" the exact name of your forward or R1 sequence file\" input_reverse.fq.gz = \" the exact name of your forward or R2 sequence file\" output_forward_paired.fq.gz = write in what you would like the output to be called Eg. 3A_trimmed_R1_paired.fastq.gz\" output_forward_unpaired.fq.gz = write in what you would like the output to be called Eg. 3A_trimmed_R1_unpaired.fastq.gz\" output_reverse_paired.fq.gz = write in what you would like the output to be called Eg. 3A_trimmed_R2_paired.fastq.gz\" output_reverse_unpaired.fq.gz = write in what you would like the output to be called Eg. 3A_trimmed_R2_unpaired.fastq.gz\" Try to run this command as it is with quality of Q15 (SLIDINGWINDOW:4:15) as currently stated in the command and then with Q30 (SLIDINGWINDOW:4:30). Record the number % of out put sequences per each. ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1211,"key":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"url":"http:\/\/www.usadellab.org\/cms\/?page=trimmomatic"}},{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":5006,"guid":"A6FE25A8CC8142A8A7CE49BCE370AF90","name":"java -jar \/storage\/BioInfo_tools\/Trimmomatic-0.36\/trimmomatic-0.36.jar PE -threads 5 -phred33 input_forward.fq.gz input_reverse.fq.gz output_forward_paired.fq.gz output_forward_unpaired.fq.gz output_reverse_paired.fq.gz output_reverse_unpaired.fq.gz ILLUMINACLIP:\/opt\/BioInfo_tools\/Trimmomatic-0.36\/adapters\/TruSeq3-PE.fa:2:30:10 LEADING:15 TRAILING:15 SLIDINGWINDOW:4:15 MINLEN:36","description":"input_forward.fq.gz = L6_R1_subset.fastq\ninput_reverse.fq.gz = L6_R2_subset.fastq","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"input_forward.fq.gz = L6_R1_subset.fastq\ninput_reverse.fq.gz = L6_R2_subset.fastq","can_edit":true}}],"guid":"1EBA3A854D7F45C0BFF3BD435DE00843","id":675077,"previous_id":675072,"previous_guid":"F27DE6AE1086465F94FA40D68EB8A877","section":"Assuring DNA sequencing quality using Trimmomatic"}
steps.section: Assuring DNA sequencing quality using Trimmomatic

steps.data: {"blocks":[{"key":"9jgm3","text":"\u00a0VizBin is a java software that calculates kmer composition and creats a pictographical output that shows the similatity between contigs realted to how close they are postition to each other. We will use VizBin to help us de-contaminate out bins","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1u24o","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7gblh","text":"VizBin will generate a visualization window. Each point represents a genomic fragment (by default of length >= 1,000nt).\u00a0VizBin is designed with the user in mind. All that is needed is a fasta file containing the sequences of interest. A step-by-step guide on using VizBin - including a description of loading the data, selecting points, and exporting the sequences represented by the selected points - is provided on the tutorial page of VizBin's github wiki","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":439,"length":20,"key":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"5hrvi","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9695u","text":"In order to run VizBin with you data you must download you bins fasta files onto your desktop.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"h7q3","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1svp6","text":"To download go to the\u00a0VizBin page","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":22,"length":11,"key":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"url":"https:\/\/github.com\/claczny\/VizBin\/wiki\/Tutorial"}},{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"url":"http:\/\/claczny.github.io\/VizBin\/"}}],"guid":"F8B798FA51DC401FBEF6D7A275F7E108","id":675078,"previous_id":675076,"previous_guid":"307A5C7A8AFB42879E2591A87D8BA9DB","section":"Use VizBin to further curate your bins"}
steps.section: Use VizBin to further curate your bins

steps.data: {"blocks":[{"key":"7odjm","text":"Phylosift software searches for single copy marker genes and finds thier taxonomic classification","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d50c","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5lt04","text":"Before running this command take a moment to learn about the sorftware at the Phylosift webpage","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":78,"length":17,"key":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"5ub82","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"url":"https:\/\/phylosift.wordpress.com\/tutorials\/running-phylosift\/illumina-tutorial\/"}},{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":5007,"guid":"1A8895F802384F09AF2991C7220CE8E6","name":"\/usr\/local\/phylosift_v1.0.1\/bin\/phylosift all your_bin.fasta --threads 3","description":"To run Phylosfit you only need to have change your_bin.fasta for the files (and path if required) for each of your individual bins","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"To run Phylosfit you only need to have change your_bin.fasta for the files (and path if required) for each of your individual bins","can_edit":true}}],"guid":"BC5E8996E1B74857B93A6AD0215D4089","id":675079,"previous_id":675078,"previous_guid":"F8B798FA51DC401FBEF6D7A275F7E108","section":"Perform taxonomic identification using Phylosift"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8drpq","text":"Learn about how to set up a prokka run and what the outputs are by looking at the git hub prokka webpage","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":90,"length":14,"key":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"eifok","text":" First export the executable files in the bin directory : export PATH=$PATH:/opt/BioInfo_tools/prokka-1.11/bin/ Then run PROKKA: /opt/BioInfo_tools/prokka-1.11/bin/prokka contigs.fasta We will annotated our curated bins using PROKKA ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":233,"key":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"url":"https://github.com/tseemann/prokka#output-files"}},{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":5008,"guid":"3991E6399FA946CFAF1E6CE12E3CB4A9","name":"First export the executable files in the bin directory :
export PATH=$PATH:/opt/BioInfo_tools/prokka-1.11/bin/

Then run PROKKA:
/opt/BioInfo_tools/prokka-1.11/bin/prokka contigs.fasta","description":"We will annotated our curated bins using PROKKA","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"We will annotated our curated bins using PROKKA","can_edit":true}}],"guid":"DDCD05D6ADA04E9F81D58AA066DBCA46","id":675080,"previous_id":675079,"previous_guid":"BC5E8996E1B74857B93A6AD0215D4089","section":"Prokka - software for annotations"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"20apd","text":"In order to assess the metabolic potential of you Metagenome Assembled Genomes (MAGs) we will compare their predicted proteins against a few different databases. These databases will provide information about what pathways or protein groups your annotated proteins belong to. This will help you assess what kind of metabolic potential your organisms possess.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1u3c5","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fvfgh","text":"We will start by taking our annotated proteins and running it in the BlastKoala web platform. http:\/\/www.kegg.jp\/blastkoala\/ ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bsejs","text":"Use your PROKKA.faa file to copy the protein annotations and past on the box label Enter FASTA sequences or upload the PROKKA.faa file. Add you email so they can keep you update on the progress of your analysis.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"con7r","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aqshb","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5i9ht","text":"Once you submit your PROKKA.faa and receive an email that your results are ready to view. Go to the View tab on top of the pie chart and press download details to get information about what metabolic pathway your proteins are associated with. After doing this, go back to the pie chart webpage and click on the Reconstruct Modules link at the bottom of the page. This will show metabolic pathways and in the detailed tab will show you which of your proteins fall within each pathways. Copy this and use as a text or save as PDF (by using Safari web browser)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f07pn","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cmva3","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"853B4A544FD245EF9AD49320C9D70C30","id":675081,"previous_id":675080,"previous_guid":"DDCD05D6ADA04E9F81D58AA066DBCA46","section":"Compare genomes to various databases"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"30rt0","text":"Compare annotated proteins to the Cluster of Orthologous Genes (COG)\u00a0","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c6s12","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"7vm2m","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":5009,"guid":"9C96D26A81C04BFEACDDF9A0EAF1C1B0","name":"rpsblast -query PROKKA.faa_file (include the path if necessary)  -db \/opt\/BioInfo_tools\/Cog -out output_file.out -evalue 0.00001 -outfmt \"6 qseqid sseqid evalue pident score qstart qend sstart send length slen\" -max_target_seqs 1","description":"","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"","can_edit":true}},{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":5010,"guid":"F696DDF576354F64AB99ADF9DD5DA97D","name":"perl \/opt\/BioInfo_tools\/cdd2cog.pl -r output_file.out -c \/opt\/BioInfo_tools\/COG\/cddid.tbl -f \/opt\/BioInfo_tools\/COG\/fun.txt -w \/opt\/BioInfo_tools\/COG\/whog -a","description":"Once we have generated a blast output, which provides a comparison of our annotated bins to the COG database we can use the cdd2cog perl script to count and parse that information for us","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"Once we have generated a blast output, which provides a comparison of our annotated bins to the COG database we can use the cdd2cog perl script to count and parse that information for us","can_edit":true}}],"guid":"31CCA6C84A69469799A0EB4147DE3952","id":675082,"previous_id":675083,"previous_guid":"D4D17DAA49C54E3F88045C2575AC0DCF","section":"Compare genomes to various databases"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ccdjg","text":"In order to run the next few steps we need to add another set of software to our path","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f6kdo","text":" nano .bashrc ##copy and paste User specific aliases and functions export PATH=$PATH:/opt/ncbi-blast-2.7.1+/bin/ ## Save file changes by "control + O" and then "control + X", then close the window and log in again to the server This step is crucial to successfully run the next few steps ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":288,"key":0}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"command","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":5011,"guid":"828C89B871474ADDAD1ECE4429B87A87","name":"nano .bashrc

##copy and paste

User specific aliases and functions 
export PATH=$PATH:/opt/ncbi-blast-2.7.1+/bin/

## Save file changes by "control + O" and then "control + X", then close the window and log in again to the server","description":"This step is crucial to successfully run the next few steps ","os_name":"","os_version":"","command":"This step is crucial to successfully run the next few steps ","can_edit":true}}],"guid":"D4D17DAA49C54E3F88045C2575AC0DCF","id":675083,"previous_id":675081,"previous_guid":"853B4A544FD245EF9AD49320C9D70C30","section":"Compare genomes to various databases"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ag3rk","text":"In order to assess the community composition of the whole metagenome we can use phylosift to find short pieces of markers in our reads. While running Phylosift with out bins\/genomes takes maybe one to a few hours running Phylosift with millions of reads will take multiple hours to days. For this reason we need to use a a window manager software call tmux . tmux will allow us to set up a process\/job to run in a parallel window and exit the window while the process keeps running in the background. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bbou8","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"af1s4","text":"In order to run Phylosift using tmux :","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"42cd2","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"36b8l","text":" \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0- Type =\u00a0tmux new -s session-name \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0example of a session-name - phylosft_3B","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bb8a5","text":" \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0- On the new window write your script command for Phylosift","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b6q84","text":" \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\/usr\/local\/phylosift_v1.0.1\/bin\/phylosift all --paired R1.fastq R2.fastq ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f5h5h","text":" \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0- Verify that is running by typing =\u00a0tmux ls","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"civks","text":" \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0- Press together the keys \u00a0control+b+z in your keyboard to disconnect from the parallel window ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5f1dp","text":"\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0- To go back to that window type \u00a0= tmux a -t\u00a0session-name \u00a0 \u00a0 for example\u00a0tmux a -t\u00a0phylosft_3B","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"85d67","text":"\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0- If something went terrible wrong you can kill your parallel window by typing =\u00a0tmux kill-session -t\u00a0phylosft_3B","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"46h2v","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"968p3","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"D8986AAD14414E429AFFD06C4E682451","id":675084,"previous_id":675082,"previous_guid":"31CCA6C84A69469799A0EB4147DE3952","section":"Running Phylosift on metagenomic reads using tmux"}
steps.section: Running Phylosift on metagenomic reads using tmux

steps.data: {"blocks":[{"key":"172u0","text":"Given that we decided that we will be working with megahit assemblies - we will use the final_contigs.fa file to run both PROKKA on the full metagenome ( as opposed to bins recovered from the metagenome) and COG on the full metagenome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"15m6n","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"pcko","text":"To do this use the same commands as above for both PROKKA and COG, but change the fasta file to the final_contigs.fa from your whole metagenome","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"47817F379F654AB09A2C760B93B8E216","id":675085,"previous_id":675084,"previous_guid":"D8986AAD14414E429AFFD06C4E682451","section":"Running PROKKA and COG on your metagenomic contigs"}
steps.section: Running PROKKA and COG on your metagenomic contigs
